data.text: Cycling Sunglasses with Prescription
Looking for the best sunglasses for cycling that I can use with a prescription. Any recommendations?
I'm partial to Smith Optics. But there are several great brands out there. Good luck!

data.text: I have Maui Jim. The customer service and quality is unparalleled.

data.text: It really depends on your prescription strength. Some of the curved lenses can‚Äôt be made in the stronger corrections. The Rudy Project inserts are quite flat, so they work with stronger correction. Best to consult your local optician to see what they recommend before ordering anything online.
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: If your prescription allows it get the frame you like with the Oakley Prizm Lenses
data.author: Ionut Bogdan Sandru

data.text: Depends on how strong a prescription you have Very strong and going between both can cause headaches due to different positions on your face And why I use clip ons sunglasses
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: I spent $700 on Oakleys and the coating came off within a year. Sweat evidently eats the coatings off. They were warranty replaced when they became so bad I couldn‚Äôt see through them. Same thing, within 6 months the coatings had dissolved again. My Optometrist told be they were the worst to deal with. Now using Maui Jim. I‚Äôll never buy any more Oakleys. YMMV though.

data.author: Robert Martinez

data.text: You really are best going to an optician for this one, some glasses have a curve to the front and this won't be suitable with some prescriptions, so they won't work for you. I really like this O'Neill Alameda 2.0 (005P) Sunglasses, but they worked for me and you need a lot of self confidence to pull them off. but also your optician can talk you through what kind of lens, polarising etc. I had been running inserts for a while and I now know why they didn't really work for me.
data.author: Sufyan Saleem

data.text: When you ride you are likely to look out of the top of the lens with your head tilted down due to aero position and drop bars etc.. Make sure your optician knows that and sets the lens center where you look out from, in my prescription it made a huge difference and was about 10mm above the normal center. Lens perscription changes depending on where in teh curve you look as the lens is two different concave and convex surfaces and not a uniform lens thickness. I even had Oakly make gold mirrored lenses with that compensation as I look ouot the top edge of my glasses when I ride. Also "wind" test the frames ride them before investing to insure you don't get breeze behind the lenses at speed, My regular prescriptions do that and my eyes constantly water with my normal glasses.
data.author: Rick Everett

data.text: I've had Rad8 504s for around 6 years and 2 different prescriptions I find them really comfy and the transition from clear to dark really quick and effective

data.text: Check the out Bose integrated bone induction headphones. You can‚Äôt get them in prescription and they keep your ear canal open while riding. Works extremely well. https://www.bose.com/en_us/products/frames/bose-frames-tempo.html#v=bose_frames_tempo_black_us

data.text: I have some Rad8 photochromic glasses that I highly rate because, unlike most variable lenses, they go completely clear in low light levels. They also do a prescription version. They are less curved than many bike glasses, so should be better for a wider range of prescriptions too. https://www.rad8.co.uk/store/p53/Rad8_504_-_Photochromic%2C_Prescription_Lenses_-_Navy_Blue_Frame.html
